creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription:
by Gekka Nagame: Sono imai/ shi no ji kirō te/ noshi-awabi/ uchikaeshi hosu/ ama kaitonami (Avoinding bad luck/ fisherman who makes auspicious dried-abalone/ don\'t ever say \"shi\" [death]./ Working under the glittering sun/ how fortunate to have such a life.)

by Yamamichi Nuime: Noshi-awabi/ kasumi no ami ni/ kakete hosu/ hikagen mo yoki/ haru no urarasa (Making dried-abalone/ by hanging it on/ a hazy net./ What a wonderful/ warm spring day!)

by Kado Marume: Mizu irazu/ meoto kasegi no/ noshi-awabi/ futa-michi kakenu/ naka zo mutsuma ji (A wife and husband/ all by themselves/ making dried-abalone./ Like dried-abalone strips/ they\'ll never break apart.)

by Kanjinsha Nijinari: Ami no me no/ kasumi mo hare te/ noshi ni suru/ awabi shunju no/ tama no haruke ki (Mists in the nets/ have vanished./ Let\'s start making dried-abalone!/ Here comes the spring light/ looking like a abalone\'s pearl.)

秋長堂物簗 Shūchōdō Butsuryō: Haru wa nao/ kokemusu iwao/ shūgi niwa/ tusite hanare nu/ uchiawabi kana (Moss on rocks/ becomes greener in spring./ Let\'s commemorate life/ by sending dried-abalone strips./ It is a neccessary part of the celebration.)
